modules.description: This module directly manipulates the DOM to build and display slideshows using Reveal.js. It provides functions to create slide elements, apply themes, load CSS and JavaScript assets, and configure the presentation. Concrete use cases include generating HTML slides from OCaml code, embedding interactive elements, and customizing Reveal.js behavior through configuration options.

This module configures and initializes a presentation interface with options to control navigation, appearance, and behavior. It defines a configuration record with boolean flags and settings for transitions, slide timing, and display features. Use it to customize presentation settings like auto-sliding, touch and keyboard input, fragment visibility, and remote control.

This module provides utilities for managing web presentation resources through path concatenation and asset organization, working primarily with string-based file paths, URLs, and color theme identifiers. It supports configuring Reveal.js presentations by specifying theme variants (like white, black, or night) and structuring dependencies for HTML/JS environments. The operations enable dynamic styling and resource loading in web-based slide decks.

This module enables the creation and manipulation of presentation slides with customizable transitions, themes, and layouts, supporting visual effects like fade, zoom, and convex animations. It operates on data structures representing slide content (e.g., titles, lists, styled text), transition types, color schemes, and animation configurations. It is used to programmatically generate slide decks, apply consistent visual styles, and manage transitions or dynamic content in interactive presentations.

This module builds and manages interactive web-based presentations using Reveal.js, handling DOM manipulation, slide structure, and visual styling. It provides data types for slides, transitions, themes, and configuration settings, with operations to create, customize, and animate slide content programmatically. You can generate HTML presentations from OCaml code, apply themes like "black" or "night", control transitions between slides, and embed interactive elements. Specific uses include building dynamic slide decks with consistent styling, enabling remote control, and configuring navigation and display behavior through code.
